author: Heriberto MuÃ±oz
title: Padres de San Diego cancelan su FanFest 2024
text: Padres de San Diego cancelan su FanFest 2024 Debido a los pronosticos del clima para este fin de semana, los Padres de San Diego cancelaron la ediciÃ³n 2024 de su FanFest e informaron que recompensarÃ¡n a sus aficionados. Por los pronÃ³sticos del clima, los Padres de San Diego decidieron cancelar su ediciÃ³n 2024 del FanFest que tenÃ­an programada para este domingo en Petco Park. Para los aficionados que retiraron por medio de su portal los boletos que eran gratuitos, se les darÃ¡ a cambio entradas para los juegos de preparaciÃ³n ante los Marineros de Seattle que se jugarÃ¡n el lunes 25 de marzo a las 18:40 y el martes 26 a las 13:10. Te puede interesar: [Â¡Se perderÃ¡ a Messi! Fan de Rayados intenta usar boleto filtrado vs Inter de Miami y acaba muy mal](https://www.elimparcial.com/deporte/2024/03/21/se-perdera-a-messi-fan-de-rayados-intenta-usar-boleto-filtrado-vs-inter-de-miami-y-acaba-muy-mal/) FanFest canceled due to weather.â€” Annie Heilbrunn (@annieheilbrunn) [#Padres] [pic.twitter.com/esgvNdL3B9] [March 22, 2024] â€œDebido a las expectativas del clima que incluyen la posibilidad de tormenta elÃ©ctrica, fuertes lluvias y vientoâ€, explicaron como las razones de su cancelaciÃ³n mediante un boletÃ­n. El FanFest de este aÃ±o contemplaba un juego de celebridades de Softbol donde participarÃ­an Brandon Moreno, Rey Mysterio Jr, Landon Donovan, Drew Brees, Alex Morgan. We will be honoring our beloved former Chairman and Owner, Peter Seidler, with a celebration of life ceremony atâ€” San Diego Padres (@Padres) [@PetcoPark]on Saturday, March 23 at 1pm PT ðŸ’› Details: [https://t.co/aQBqPu9PU0] [pic.twitter.com/ONSjNDFoDz] [February 8, 2024] En el comunicado se explicÃ³ que los aficionados pueden elegir entre el primero juego o segundo ante Marineros de Seattle y los asientos serÃ¡n los de la parte superior del estadio. El primer nivel de asientos, como parte de la celebraciÃ³n de los 20 aÃ±os de Petco Park, se mantendrÃ¡ con un costo de 20 dÃ³lares para adultos y 10 para niÃ±os. Te puede interesar: [Regresa JosÃ© â€˜ChapulÃ­nâ€™ Salas a boxear en TJ tras sparrings con Inoue](https://www.elimparcial.com/deporte/2024/03/21/regresa-jose-chapulin-salas-a-boxear-en-tj-tras-sparrings-con-inoue/) Este sÃ¡bado tendrÃ¡n una celebraciÃ³n de la vida de su difunto propietario Peter Seidler, misma que tambiÃ©n se moviÃ³ un par de horas por las condiciones climatolÃ³gicas. Con el nuevo horario, el evento darÃ¡ inicio a las 11:00 de este sÃ¡bado 23 de marzo. For Peter.â€” San Diego Padres (@Padres) For San Diego. For The Faithful. [pic.twitter.com/qZjtItbWUn] [March 1, 2024]

author: Tim Spears
title: How surgeons use artificial intelligence in operating rooms - NewsBreak
text: INDIANAPOLIS (WISH) â€” OrthoIndy is pioneering the use of artificial intelligence in operating rooms, even using it to guide invasive surgery. Itâ€™s one of five sites using Surgical Theater , an AI imaging technology, for spinal surgery. OrthoIndy spinal surgeon Dr. Greg Poulter said, â€œItâ€™s a tool for the artisan. If you really care as a surgeon about doing a better job, this tool is revolutionary.â€ Partly developed from fighter pilot training technology, Surgical Theater builds a 3D model to help plan a surgery, practice techniques, and guide the surgeon through the planned procedure. Itâ€™s not generative AI, where the software fabricates images or fills in the blanks. Surgical Theaterâ€™s AI imaging is based on CT scans and MRIs, which Poulter says is accurate within the millimeter. Using a headset, a surgeon can view an augmented reality roadmap of the patientâ€™s anatomy along with a pre-planned method to operate; guiding the surgery. â€œHistorically in spine surgery, weâ€™re looking at an MRI or an X-ray. â€¦ Then we come to the operating room with our patient, and we just have to figure out how weâ€™re going to do it,â€ Poulter said. Surgical Theater â€œprovides not only a level of safety thatâ€™s never been there before, but a level of precision.â€ Luke Isenbarger had put off treating his back for years, living with pain on a daily basis. â€œIt has an effect on everything. Your daily attitude, your daily lifestyle, and not being able to keep up with the kids, physically.â€ After consulting with professionals at OrthoIndy, he felt comfortable going through with surgery, largely because he could see how the procedure would happen through the virtual model. â€œTo me, itâ€™s genius,â€ Insenbarger said. Twenty-two sites are using the technology for brain surgery.

author: Richard Tzul
title: Westchester Park Exempt from Property Tax, New York Court Rules
text:
A park in Westchester County, N.Y., can keep its property tax exemption because itâ€™s public, a state appellate court said Wednesday.
- The county hired a private entity to manage and operate the park, but the park is still owned by the government and used for public purposes, the court said
- Standard Amusements LLC managed the park but still needed to request the countyâ€™s permission to make changes to the space, the unsigned opinion said
- The agreement between Westchester and Standard Amusements says that the company has no â€œpossessory rightâ€ to Playland Park, which is located in the city of Rye ...

author: Tiffany Rigby
title: 3 Midlands people indicted in interstate child sex trafficking conspiracy - ABC Columbia
text: COLUMBIA, S.C (WOLO)â€“ A federal grand jury in Columbia returned a 10-count indictment charging three Columbia-area defendants in a child sex trafficking conspiracy , said the Department of Justice. Antonio Marquis Nicholson, 32, of West Columbia, was charged with human trafficking conspiracy, three counts sex trafficking of a minor, three counts coercion and enticement of a minor, interstate travel to promote illegal sexual activity, interstate transportation of a minor for illegal sexual activity, and one count of witness tampering. Rebecca Melanie Perry, 30, of Columbia, South Carolina and Augusta, Georgia, was charged with human trafficking conspiracy, sex trafficking of a minor, coercion and enticement of a minor, and interstate travel to promote illegal sexual activity. Terrell Counts, 33, of Columbia, was charged with three counts coercion and enticement of a minor. And a fourth defendant Monesha Tatayana Lapri Gary, 24, of Clinton, was also indicted with them and charged with human trafficking conspiracy, three counts of sex trafficking of a minor, and three counts of coercion and enticement of a minor. Investigators say between December 2022 and July 2023 Nicholson, Gary, and Perry enticed, transported, harbored, and maintained at least three minor victims in the commercial sex trade. They are accused of finding victims who were minors and runaways, then provided them with lingerie, obtained photographs, and advertised the victims on the internet for commercial sex. Also, they are accused of communicating with customers and arranging commercial sex for customers with the minors and then confiscated proceeds. The indictment further alleges that Nicholson and Perry travelled across state lines, and that Nicholson took a minor from North Carolina to South Carolina for the purposes of illegal sexual activity. Nicholson, Gary, and Perry face a mandatory 15 years in prison while Counts faces a mandatory 10 years, and each defendant faces up to life in prison, said officials. The defendants also face life terms of supervision by the federal court following any term of imprisonment, sex offender registration, and mandatory restitution payable to victims. Gary and Counts were ordered by a judge to be detained pending any trial or bond hearing. Nicholson and Perry will be arraigned on Jan. 30 at 10:00 a.m.

author: Agence France-Presse
title: Muchova to skip Australian Open over wrist injury
text: World number eight Karolina Muchova said on Thursday, Dec. 28, she would skip next year's Australian Open because of a persistent wrist injury which already ruled her out of this year's WTA Finals. Muchova to skip Australian Open over wrist injury At a glance PRAGUE (AFP) -- World number eight Karolina Muchova said on Thursday, Dec. 28, she would skip next year's Australian Open because of a persistent wrist injury which already ruled her out of this year's WTA Finals. "This isn't my favorite thing to share especially at the start of a new season, but unfortunately the pain in a wrist came back in the middle of my tennis preparation," she said on Facebook. "I therefore have to postpone the start of the season and fully heal my wrist first." "It's frustrating but I have to keep positive, recover and get ready for the rest of the year. See you in 2025, Australian Open," added the 27-year-old Czech. Muchova injured her right wrist at the US Open in September, where she reached the semifinals. In her best season so far, Muchova also reached the French Open final this year and climbed the WTA rankings from 149th at the end of 2022 to the current eighth spot. Muchova's best result at the Australian Open so far was a semifinal loss in 2021.

author: Anke Backhaus
title: Ortsring Birgelen spendet: 9900 Euro fÃ¼r Kinder Ã¼bergeben
text:
Der Nikolausmarkt in Birgelen im unteren Bereich der MÃ¼hlenstraÃŸe ist stets gut besucht. Da macht es besonders viel Freude, sich auf das bevorstehende Weihnachtsfest einzustimmen. Da ist dann das ganze Dorf mit seinen Bewohnerinnen und Bewohnern unterwegs, auch jeder einzelne der 20 Ortsvereine engagiert sich. Hinzu kommen dann auch die Besucherinnen und Besucher. Nur gut, dass der Ortsring Birgelen, unter dessen Dach die Vereinswelt des Ortes zusammenkommt, auch einen Sinn fÃ¼r Soziales hat â€“ und so hat der Ortsring Birgelen eine Spende in HÃ¶he von insgesamt 9900 Euro Ã¼bergeben.
â€žDer Mensch muss im Vordergrund stehen. In der Hauptsache geht es uns darum, Kinder zu unterstÃ¼tzenâ€œ, sagt Ortsring-Vorsitzender Andreas ThiÃŸen. Er fÃ¼hrt weiter aus: â€žImmer rund um den Nikolaustag ist das ganze Dorf auf den Beinen. Jeder macht etwas, jeder erledigt seine Aufgabe. Darum kÃ¶nnen wir auf jeden Fall sagen: Diese Spendensumme kommt aus unserem ganzen Dorf.â€œ
Das Geld teilt sich so auf: Je 1500 Euro erhalten der FÃ¶rderverein der Katholischen Grundschule in Birgelen, die Schatzsucher Wassenberg, die Kindermission Birgelen. je 1350 Euro gehen an den FÃ¶rderverein der KindertagesstÃ¤tte Sankt Lambertus in Birgelen, an das Integrationsnetzwerk Initiative Autismus, die Insel Tobi und erneut die Kindermission Birgelen, die Ã¼brigens jedes Jahr begÃ¼nstigt ist, ansonsten versuchen die Birgelener, immer andere Stellen zu finden, wo eine Spende dringend benÃ¶tigt wird.
Wie entscheidend Spenden sind, machten die Vertreter der MÃ¶nchengladbacher Insel Tobi klar. Die Insel ist eine Kurzzeitpflege fÃ¼r SÃ¤uglinge, Kinder, Jugendliche und junge Erwachsene bis zu 21 Jahren mit lebenslimitierenden Erkrankungen. Staatliche Hilfe gibt es nicht, Spenden sind daher unerlÃ¤sslich. Auch Kinder aus dem Kreis Heinsberg werden dort betreut. Die Einrichtung ist allein deshalb wichtig, um beispielsweise den Eltern wichtige Auszeiten zu ermÃ¶glichen, damit auch sie neue KrÃ¤fte schÃ¶pfen kÃ¶nnen.
Zu den weiteren BegÃ¼nstigten zÃ¤hlt das Integrationsnetzwerk Initiative Autismus. Einer der Standorte befindet sich in Heinsberg. Das Netzwerk betreibt viel AufklÃ¤rungsarbeit, unter anderem an Schulen, denn: â€žAutismus ist oftmals nicht klar zu erkennenâ€œ, hieÃŸ es bei der SpendenÃ¼bergabe.
In der Region gut bekannt sind die Schatzsucher, die trauernde Kinder und Jugendliche auffangen und mit unterschiedlichen Projekten versuchen, der Trauer Raum zu geben und die teils sehr jungen Menschen zu stÃ¤rken.
Und auch in der Birgelener Grundschule ist die Spende willkommen. Schulleiterin Barbara Schillings unterstrich, dass es die Kinder sein werden, die im SchÃ¼lerparlament darÃ¼ber entscheiden, was mit dem Geld geschieht. Ã„hnlich verfÃ¤hrt der Kindergarten, fÃ¼r den Einrichtungsleiterin Ilona Meisen betonte, dass die Kinder den Weg der Nachhaltigkeit gehen wollen und das Geld in dem Zusammenhang eingesetzt werden wird.

author: Nelson Espinal
title: 'I had a monster tumor that grew its own teeth and ate my ovary' - NewsBreak
text:
A teenager's childhood love for Harry Potter creatures has transformed into a terrifying reality after doctors discovered "monster tumors" growing teeth and eyes and consuming her ovaries. Nesli Meir was on vacation in Guatemala last month (January 16) when she experienced sharp pain in the lower right side of her abdomen. After enduring agony for two days, the 17-year-old went to the hospital, where a CT scan revealed a benign teratoma tumor, commonly referred to as a "monster tumor." Germ cell tumors can appear at any age and develop from cells that produce eggs or sperm. They are most commonly found in the ovaries or testes; however, one or more may develop in other body parts, such as the abdomen. The symptoms depend on where the tumor grows. Typically, it starts with a lump that can be felt, and it may cause other symptoms, such as a swollen stomach. READ MORE: Minnesota inmate died slowly from perforated ulcer as staff 'blamed withdrawal and ignored cries' READ MORE: Doctor who diagnosed her own stage 4 colon cancer shares key warning sign A benign tumor can be cured if it is removed through surgery, which may involve removing a testicle or an ovary, depending on where the tumor originated. If the tumor is malignant and can be completely removed through surgery, chemotherapy is not always necessary, especially if it begins in the testis or ovary. If the tumor cannot be easily removed or has spread, chemotherapy will be administered. The scan showed that Nesli's "tennis-ball-sized" mass had developed a tooth, while a week later, an ultrasound in San Diego, California, indicated that it might even have an eyeball. Doctors discovered a second "fingertip-sized" teratoma, which prompted her to name the pair Terry and Tommy and share light-hearted TikTok videos to "make light" of the concerning situation. Her mother, Rachel Silber, mentions that Nesli adored Harry Potter and wished for the franchise's Book of Monsters as a cake for her birthday. Click here to follow the Mirror US on Google News to stay up to date with all the latest news, sports and entertainment stories. The 55-year-old jokes that Nesli has "internalized" the sweet treat by having the "monster tumors," though she acknowledges that the revelation is "strange" and "freaks her out." Initially, Nesli thought she had appendicitis, but now she fears she might need to have her right ovary removed because the large mass means she "doesn't have much tissue left." "I got a really sharp pain in the bottom right of my abdomen while traveling, and I went really nauseous and white," she said. "I thought it was nothing because I'd had them [pains] my whole life, and they would go away after half an hour. This one didn't go away, so I had to go to the doctor. They said it could be appendicitis or a cyst, so I thought it was appendicitis at first. The CT scan showed I had a teratoma, and it was really scary because of how big it is." "They narrowed it down to a teratoma because it has calcification, which means [it has] a tooth. The lady that did the ultrasound said there is a spot that could be an eyeball because it has liquid in it, so we're waiting until the surgery to find out. I've named the tumors Terry and Tommy to make fun of the situation. The pain is really bad, and I try to tune it out, but it's still lingering. They said I might have to get the whole ovary removed because there isn't a lot of ovarian tissue left on the side with the bigger teratoma." "I'm afraid of surgery, so I'm not looking forward to having that done. They will see what's in it when they take it out of me, but I researched what they might grow, and one girl had a whole jaw in hers. That freaks me out. The video I made definitely helps me make light of the situation, and [I get to] see people who are going to get their pain checked. Someone made fan art of the tumors, and I will put it up as a poster in my room. The whole thing is a crazy ride. If anything hurts in that area and won't go away for more than a day I would definitely tell people to get it checked." Nesli was informed that tooth growth occurs due to calcification, a process in which elevated calcium levels lead to tissue hardening. She is awaiting surgery to determine precisely what else is present in the teratomas. Still, she mentioned that the presence of fluid inside the large one suggests there might be an eyeball. Her mother, Rachel, from San Diego, California, stated: "It's really strange. This is a new thing for us because we hadn't heard the word teratoma before, and it means monster tumor. This little kiddo grew up with Harry Potter and wanted The Monster Book of Monsters as a birthday cake, so I joke with her and say she internalised her birthday cake. I'm freaked out because it's like an alien baby without it being a baby or an alien. I don't know how else to describe it. It's very different and very strange." Nesli admitted she is worried about not being able to have kids but tries to make light of the situation through videos on TikTok.
Her most viral clip has more than 18 million views and 13,000 comments.

author: Patrick Davies
title: Anti-SOGI 123 groupâ€™s Cariboo book ban call fails to gain traction - The Abbotsford News
text: Neither the Cariboo Regional District nor School District 27 (Cariboo-Chilcotin) plan to remove any books from their libraries, despite a request recently to ban several SOGI 123 books. On Jan. 9 a delegation to the district of 100 Mile Houseâ€™s regular council meeting asked for councilâ€™s support in the banning of 68 books, available at public and school libraries, they deemed as SOGI 123 resources. SOGI 123 is a resource that supports educators in addressing sexual orientations and gender identities topics in the provincial curriculum. SOGI stands for Sexual Orientations and Gender Identities, while the 123 is meant to reflect creating an inclusive education environment being â€˜as easy as 1-2-3,â€™ notes B.C.â€™s education ministry. The delegationâ€™s spokesman Marty Blazina said that in his view all the books were inappropriate and should be removed from the shelves. Around 60 people attended the meeting, both supporters and opponents of the delegation. â€œThere are 68 SOGI titles in the 100 Mile area that are to one degree or another, sexually explicit and or pornographic. Today, Iâ€™m going to look briefly at five of these titles,â€ Blazina said during his presentation. The five books he referenced were Identical, by Ellen Hopkins with a target audience of 14+; Itâ€™s Perfectly Normal, by Robbie H. Harris target audience of 10+; Gender Queer, an autobiography by Maia Kobabe with a target audience of 16+; Fun Home by Alison Bechdel target audience 15+ and Sex is A Funny Word, a comic book by sex educator Cory Silverberg and illustrated by Fiona Smyth for ages 8-10. Blazina drew attention to certain passages in the books and what he described as the graphic nature of the illustrations. At the end of the presentation, Blazina said he hoped it had given those present cause for alarm and that SOGI 123 was not welcome in 100 Mile. After the presentation, Mayor Maureen Pinkney thanked Blazina and the rest of the delegation for attending and being respectful. â€œWe truly appreciate each and every one of you for coming out today and showing your support or not, as there could be both sides here,â€ she said. â€œThis is how we do learn about things and try to help and deal with things is by people coming and talking to us and making us aware.â€ The mayor promised to reach out to CRD board chair Margo Wagner on the subject. Wagner said Pinkney passed along the concerns of this group of South Cariboo residents after the meeting. However, at this time neither she nor the CRD plan to remove or ban any of the books on the list from the CRD Library in 100 Mile House. â€œAs elected officials we represent all people within our area and obviously not all of them are going to agree with one another,â€ Wagner said. â€œWe give time to both sides. In this particular issue, the CRD feels that we have a responsibility to ensure that the books are in an age-appropriate area. As far as pulling books, the CRD is not planning on doing this.â€ Wagner said those sharing Blazinaâ€™s concerns can initiate a process with the CRD to have them removed or reallocated to different parts of the library. All they need to do is pick up the necessary forms available at all library branches. â€œIf we start moving books we have people on the other side who are concerned about it. Weâ€™re trying to be fair on both sides, understanding that it is a very hot topic. Itâ€™s a hot topic at schools, on the streets and our main thing is that we represent all people within the Cariboo Regional District no matter their ethnicity, their beliefs, whatever,â€ Wagner said. â€œWe will listen to anybody but we canâ€™t always please everybody.â€ Meanwhile, Chris van der Mark, SD27â€™s superintendent of schools, said he hasnâ€™t received any communication from the district regarding the delegation. However, he said there still seems to be some misunderstanding amongst the community about what SOGI 123 is. â€œBack in 2016 the Human Rights Code changed to include some very basic rights and understanding around gender identity and sexual orientation. Those things are now in the code and respected as they should be in our society and certainly in our K-12 system,â€ van der Mark said. â€œThings are taught at an age-appropriate level as they have been going back for quite some time.â€ As societyâ€™s understanding of topics and issues change, how theyâ€™re taught changes as well, van der Mark remarked. At the end of the day, he said SOGI 123 boils down to making sure that people feel safe under the school districtâ€™s care and that no students are bullied or discriminated against because of who they are. While Blazina agreed that bullying should not happen and he would never bully anyone, he said he believes SOGI 123 is not the way to counteract bullying. He said that he made the presentation on behalf of Action4Canada, a grassroots political movement that gained prominence during the COVID-19 pandemic. van der Mark encourages parents with concerns about SOGI 123 and what resources their children may or may not have access to reach out to their local teachers and principals directly. He acknowledged it is possible some books may be in circulation that didnâ€™t get vetted properly, but said there is a process to deal with them. â€œIf youâ€™re in doubt and have a specific concern (talk to us). I donâ€™t have complaints coming in about particular books,â€ van der Mark said. â€œI understand itâ€™s a sensitive topic for a variety of folks but I do think it comes down to a basic understanding of people and each other and being kind to one another. Letâ€™s have more of that.â€ â€”With files from Fiona Grisswell. READ ALSO: [SOGI 123 enters into 7th year in B.C. classrooms](https://www.aldergrovestar.com/news/sogi-123-enters-into-7th-year-in-b-c-classrooms-2360619) READ ALSO: [PHOTOS: Anti-SOGI protests sharing misinformation, inciting hate: B.C. educators](https://www.aldergrovestar.com/news/photos-anti-sogi-protests-sharing-misinformation-inciting-hate-bc-educators-5934923)

author: Diario El Dia de La Plata www.eldia.com
title: "Tortazo" y vuelco en pleno centro de La Plata
text:
Un vehÃ­culo utilitario terminÃ³ tumbado contra el pavimento en un accidente de trÃ¡nsito ocurrido esta tarde en La Plata.
El incidente se produjo en la esquina de 6 y 56, pleno centro platense. AllÃ­, por causas que se determinarÃ¡n una Peugeot Partner colisionÃ³ con un Fiat Siena.
El conductor de la Peugeot sufriÃ³ algunas heridas, aunque estaba consiente, indicaron testigos.
"Si bien hubo una imprudencia, los autos que estacionan en las ochavas de la esquinas, dificultan la visibilidad de los conductores. De todas maneras, no justifica el tortazo".

author: @https://twitter.com/FOX13Memphis
title: Two teen boys, man arrested after running from stolen car | News | fox13memphis.com
text:
Two boys, 13 and 14, arrested with adult in stolen car, police say FOX13 Memphis News Staff FOX13 Memphis News Staff Author facebook Author twitter Author email Dec 28, 2023 1 hr ago Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Photo Credit: Shelby County Sheriff's Office Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save MEMPHIS, Tenn. - Two teen boys and a 22-year-old man were arrested after running from a stolen car, according to the Memphis Police Department (MPD).
MPD said a man was carjacked on Cotton Way in Parkway Village around 11:15 a.m. on December 22.
That man told police that a man pointed a gun at him and demanded money and his vehicle in Spanish. The man complied and the carjacker drove off in his 2010 black Toyota Corolla, MPD said.
Five days later on Wednesday, December 27, police said officers saw the stolen car around 11 a.m. at Winchester and Outland Road.
Officers tried to pull over the vehicle as it pulled into the River City Height Apartments and five people jumped out of the car and ran off on foot, according to police.
MPD said officers were able to capture three of those people, including a 13-year-old boy, a 14-year-old boy and 22-year-old Jenner Mendez.
All three have been charged with theft of property between $2,500 and $10,000 and evading arrest on foot.
Mendez's bond was set at $5,000, MPD said.

organizations.name: shelby county sheriff's office facebook twitter
